newsitem.title: USA: Los Angeles City Council approves arena plan.
newsitem.headline: Los Angeles City Council approves arena plan.

text.p: The Los Angeles City Council on Friday approved plans to build a $200 million sports and entertainment complex in the downtown area.
The vote on the memorandum of understanding capped months of negotiations over the proposed arena development for the Los Angeles Kings hockey team and the Lakers basketball team.
The council approved the business plan Friday on a vote of 11-to-3. In January, the city council tentatively approved the proposal by a vote of 13-to-2.

Under the proposal, the city would contribute about $70 million to the project. The city's contribution would be funded with a taxable debt financing of $50.5 million and $20 million from a bond reserve fund. The average annual cost of the city's contribution was estimated to be $6.8 million.

The city's contribution would be fully recovered from tax revenues generated by the arena and from other sources, city negotiators said. Developers have agreed to levy a special surcharge on arena tickets to help the city pay off the bonds.
City officials maintain that the transaction would bolster the downtown economy by creating jobs.
Critics of the plan say it would put city taxpayers at risk if the arena fails to bring in enough revenues to repay the bonds.
